children.name: Lecture 1. Turing machines and their resources
How much time does it take to sort a list of length n?
At least O(n) and at most O(n logn)
How much time does it take to check if a graph of n vertices can be 3-coloured? Each vertex gets one of 3 colours, and no edge is monochromatic.
If we only care about polynomial time (or slower), then Turing Machines are a good model of computation.
A Turing machine is a model of computation. An alternative would be Java programs.
The model is minimalistic, so that it is easier to prove theorems like: For every Turing machine M, ...
Maybe Java programs would be easier for theorems like: There is a Turing machine M such that ...
But Turing machines are fine for this, once you get used to them.
A configuration of a Turing machine looks like this:
The syntax of a deterministic Turing machine consists of:

– an input alphabet Σ – a work alphabet Γ, which contains Σ and a blank symbol – a set of states Q with a designated initial state – a transition function of the form δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})
δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})
Consider an input string, e.g. abaccbab ∈ Σ*
The machine begins in the initial configuration for this string:
Next, the machine keeps on updating its configuration, until:
– a reject transition is used, or the head falls off the tape
– the run goes on forever, avoiding accept and reject
A Turing machine induces a partial function M : Σ* ⟶ {accept, reject}
Fact. For every two-tape Turing machine, there is a one-tape machine that rejects/accepts the same inputs.
Tape that is inifinite to the left and right
The simulating Turing machine runs in time O((running time of while program) × polylog(biggest integer used))
A language L ⊆ Σ* is decidable if there is a Turing machine which: – accepts inputs from L – rejects inputs from outside L
A language L ⊆ Σ* is semi-decidable if there is a Turing machine which: – accepts inputs from L – rejects or does not terminate on inputs from outside L
Fact. If both L and its complement are semi-decidable, then L is decidable.
If both L and its complement are semi-decidable, then there are Turing machines M and N such that:
if w ∈ L then: M accepts N rejects or does not terminate
if w ∉ L then: N accepts M rejects or does not terminate
We can construct an always-halting machine for L as follows:
Take any undecidable language L ⊆ Σ*.
Example: context-free grammars that are universal.
Proof. Otherwise, “search through all proofs of PA” would be a Turing machine that decides membership in L.
Example: there is a context-free grammar, whose universality or non-universality cannot be proved
Same argument works for ZFC (set theory).
We only consider Turing machines with input alphabet {0,1}.
Such a Turing machine is represented by a binary string with: 1. the number of letters in the work alphabet 2. the number of states (initial state is 1) 3. a list of the transitions
Given an input w, we do the following.
1. If w does not represent a Turing machine, reject
Accept when an accept/reject configuration is seen.
The halting problem is not decidable
Suppose that there is a Turing machine M, which decides the halting problem.
Consider the following Turing machine N, with input alphabet {0,1}.
Does w represent a Turing machine that halts on input w?
Does N halt on (the encoding of) N?
If N does not halt on N, then N halts on N.
If N halts on N, then N does not halt on N.
Consider the smallest integer which cannot be described in ASCII string with less than 100 letters.
For a number n ∈ {0, 1, 2, ...}, define its Kołmogorow complexity to be the size of the smallest Turing machine which computes it.
Theorem. The Kołmogorow complexity cannot be computed.
Proof. Supppose that Kołmogorow complexity can be computed by a Turing machine of size 1000.
There is a least number with Kołmogorow complexity at least 2000.
This number can be computed by a Turing machine of size < 2000.
because we can write a Turing machine of size < 2000, which finds the smallest number of Kołmogorow complexity at least 2000.
In a nondeterministic Turing machine, the transition function has type
δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})
for every situation, there could be several actions to take
On a given input, a nondeterministic Turing machine can have many runs.
There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run
For inputs w ∉ L, every run either rejects, or does not halt.
There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run and w ∉ L ⟺ ∃ rejecting run
There cannot be an input which has both rejecting and accepting runs
Proof for nondeterministic semi-decidable ⊆ deterministic semi-decidable.
Do a breadth-first search in the graph of reachable configurations
1. compute all configurations reachable in 1 step from the initial one.
2. compute all configurations reachable in 2 steps from the initial one.
3. compute all configurations reachable in 3 steps from the initial one.
After some time, the tape looks like this:
When an accepting configuration is found, accept.
The same proof shows deterministic decidable = nondeterministic decidable.
Since nondeterministic Turing machines can be confusing, we sometimes use deterministic Turing machines with a read-only witness tape.
There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run
There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run and w ∉ L ⟺ ∃ rejecting run
So far, we have discussed Turing machines which terminate in finite time.
The point of computational complexity is to consider, say, polynomial time.
